2. A 28-year-old man presents with a 2-year history of worsening balance difficulties and intermittent slurred speech. He notes that he occasionally experiences tremors in his hands, especially when performing precise tasks like writing or using utensils. His family reports subtle personality changes and occasional mood swings over the past year. Neurological examination reveals wide-based gait, intentional tremor, and mild nystagmus on lateral gaze. Deep tendon reflexes are normal, and sensory examination is unremarkable. Brain MRI demonstrates moderate cerebellar atrophy predominantly affecting the vermis. His mother had a similar illness with gait difficulties starting in her early 30s. Genetic analysis identifies a pathogenic mutation in the GRM1 gene, confirming a diagnosis of Spinocerebellar Ataxia 44.
